text: Oh
I'm Roger Carr and a columnist for The
New York Times 20 years ago in Berlin
the unthinkable happened the Berlin Wall
came down and the division of Europe
ended I've asked myself ever since then
what combination of historical forces
and individual acts contributed to that
miracle clearly the decision of Mikhail
Gorbachev the Soviet leader not to use
force was one factor but in the end this
opening of the wall came down to the
decisions and acts of one single border
guard at a crossing on the Berlin Wall
that night of november nine 1989 Harold
llega spent nearly three decades working
at the bornholm a stressor border
crossing today traffic rushes by 20
years ago it was a sealed crossing
between East and West Germany llega
volunteered for the East German border
police when he was 17 in order that
whole I was brought up in the sense to
believe that you also have to do
something for the state you live in lib
the night of November 9th 1989 was just
another night on post hey I had just
started I just got my sandwiches got my
pot of tea my good I had placed him on a
table and I just take my first bite into
my mouth Aladin sis Horta sophie dee
virus I know a television in the
cafeteria was set to a live press
conference with günter schabowski a
senior East German official on this I we
have decided today to endorse a
regulation that allows every citizen of
East Germany to leave the country via
East German border crossing points a
permanent exit is possible via all East
German border crossing points to West
Germany the journalist wanted details
when does it go into effect does with
minor that comes into effect according
to my information immediately without
delay
confusion filled the guards offices they
hadn't received any order to open the
border war demo and the car traffic was
so heavy that within 11 and a half two
hours the whole border crossing point
was blocked Yeager who is the most
senior officer present called his
superiors he told them the crowd was
growing impatient chaos was brewing they
didn't believe in illegal this totally
pissed me off and I shouted into the
phone or if you don't believe me and
just listen to what's going on outside
with my limit llevarlo my staff demanded
Herod then you have to do something and
so I asked provocatively what do you
want me to do should I give the order to
shoot desperate to control the situation
the guards let a few of the most
persistent people through our but
instead of reducing the pressure it just
increased it what I should do and what I
had to do at that point was clear in
order to prevent a catastrophe in order
to prevent or rule out any panic the
only option was to open the border and
let all East German citizens leaves
after unification jager owned a
newspaper stand and worked briefly as a
security guard for a private company
before retiring to a small house and
prized garden just outside Berlin who
heard of do wrong and today I have a
very clear position to have East Germany
back I don't want this by no means with
the opening of the bourne homeless
straße gate the first floodgates were
open this was the end of East Germany
but what if what if llega had acted
differently what if he'd given the order
to fire the hypothetical has little
value in history but the fact is that it
was this one man's decision that changed
the course of history now he's an
anonymous hero few people know his name
but Jaeger played a role of absolutely
critical importance
you
